lines.text: Enter LAFEU and BERTRAM

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: But I hope your lordship thinks not him a soldier.

lines.speaker: bertram
lines.text: Yes, my lord, and of very valiant approof.

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: You have it from his own deliverance.

lines.speaker: bertram
lines.text: And by other warranted testimony.

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: Then my dial goes not true: I took this lark for a bunting.

lines.speaker: bertram
lines.text: I do assure you, my lord, he is very great in knowledge and accordingly valiant.

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: I have then sinned against his experience and transgressed against his valour; and my state that way is dangerous, since I cannot yet find in my heart to repent. Here he comes: I pray you, make us friends; I will pursue the amity.
Enter PAROLLES

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: [To BERTRAM]  These things shall be done, sir.

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: Pray you, sir, who's his tailor?

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: Sir?

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: O, I know him well, I, sir; he, sir, 's a good workman, a very good tailor.

lines.speaker: bertram
lines.text: [Aside to PAROLLES]  Is she gone to the king?

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: She is.

lines.speaker: bertram
lines.text: Will she away to-night?

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: As you'll have her.

lines.speaker: bertram
lines.text: I have writ my letters, casketed my treasure, Given order for our horses; and to-night, When I should take possession of the bride, End ere I do begin.

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: A good traveller is something at the latter end of a dinner; but one that lies three thirds and uses a known truth to pass a thousand nothings with, should be once heard and thrice beaten. God save you, captain.

lines.speaker: bertram
lines.text: Is there any unkindness between my lord and you, monsieur?

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: I know not how I have deserved to run into my lord's displeasure.

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: You have made shift to run into 't, boots and spurs and all, like him that leaped into the custard; and out of it you'll run again, rather than suffer question for your residence.

lines.speaker: bertram
lines.text: It may be you have mistaken him, my lord.

lines.speaker: lafeu
lines.text: And shall do so ever, though I took him at 's prayers. Fare you well, my lord; and believe this of me, there can be no kernel in this light nut; the soul of this man is his clothes. Trust him not in matter of heavy consequence; I have kept of them tame, and know their natures. Farewell, monsieur: I have spoken better of you than you have or will to deserve at my hand; but we must do good against evil.
Exit

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: An idle lord. I swear.

lines.speaker: bertram
lines.text: I think so.

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: Why, do you not know him?

lines.speaker: bertram
lines.text: Yes, I do know him well, and common speech Gives him a worthy pass. Here comes my clog.
Enter HELENA

lines.speaker: helena
lines.text: I have, sir, as I was commanded from you, Spoke with the king and have procured his leave For present parting; only he desires Some private speech with you.

lines.speaker: bertram
lines.text: I shall obey his will. You must not marvel, Helen, at my course, Which holds not colour with the time, nor does The ministration and required office On my particular. Prepared I was not For such a business; therefore am I found So much unsettled: this drives me to entreat you That presently you take our way for home; And rather muse than ask why I entreat you, For my respects are better than they seem And my appointments have in them a need Greater than shows itself at the first view To you that know them not. This to my mother: 'Twill be two days ere I shall see you, so I leave you to your wisdom.
Giving a letter

lines.speaker: helena
lines.text: Sir, I can nothing say, But that I am your most obedient servant.

lines.speaker: bertram
lines.text: Come, come, no more of that.

lines.speaker: helena
lines.text: And ever shall With true observance seek to eke out that Wherein toward me my homely stars have fail'd To equal my great fortune.

lines.speaker: bertram
lines.text: Let that go: My haste is very great: farewell; hie home.

lines.speaker: helena
lines.text: Pray, sir, your pardon.

lines.speaker: bertram
lines.text: Well, what would you say?

lines.speaker: helena
lines.text: I am not worthy of the wealth I owe, Nor dare I say 'tis mine, and yet it is; But, like a timorous thief, most fain would steal What law does vouch mine own.

lines.speaker: bertram
lines.text: What would you have?

lines.speaker: helena
lines.text: Something; and scarce so much: nothing, indeed. I would not tell you what I would, my lord: Faith yes; Strangers and foes do sunder, and not kiss.

lines.speaker: bertram
lines.text: I pray you, stay not, but in haste to horse.

lines.speaker: helena
lines.text: I shall not break your bidding, good my lord.

lines.speaker: bertram
lines.text: Where are my other men, monsieur? Farewell. Go thou toward home; where I will never come Whilst I can shake my sword or hear the drum. Away, and for our flight.
Exit HELENA

lines.speaker: parolles
lines.text: Bravely, coragio!
Exeunt
